mw_today: A chance of rain and snow showers before 1pm, then a slight chance of rain showers between 1pm and 2pm.  Partly sunny, with a high near 45. South wind 7 to 11 mph becoming west southwest in the afternoon.  Chance of precipitation is 40%. Little or no snow accumulation expected.
mw_tonight: Mostly cloudy, with a low around 24. South southeast wind 5 to 9 mph.
btac_hazard:
Spring warm up continues today, with above freezing temperatures expected from the valley floor to the highest peaks. A very weak system moves through today, bringing the possibility of snow showers in the mountains and rain/snow mix in the interior valleys.  Wind slabs are prevalent in the alpine and their sensitivity to triggers could increase with solar input.

Recent avalanche activity was observed in the northern portion of GTNP yesterday. Forecaster Catino observed lots of wet loose activity shedding off of steep faces and an impressive avalanche that ran to the valley floor on a south aspect (likely ran during the last storm). Avalanche activity was observed in Avalanche Canyon two days ago, mostly wind slabs that were size 1.5 or less. 

Have left the 3/20 and 3/29 persistent slab problems in place for now, but sensitivity is expected to go down after the peak heating today and subsequent refreeze tonight.  The 3/29 interface seems to be more of an issue where it is presenting as a crust, northerly aspects do not seem to be as concerning as easterlies and southerlies. The same cannot be said of the 3/20 interface where it is a layer of NSF on NNE aspects.
btac_weatherdisc:
Yesterday and Last Night: Yesterday was mostly sunny and warm, with breezy conditions on the ridgelines. Last night was partly cloudy and cool. Temperatures currently range from the upper 20s in the valleys to the upper teens on the peaks. Winds averaged out of the south at 16 mph on Rendezvous Summit over the last 24 hrs. 

Today: Today will be partly cloudy in the mountains and mostly sunny in the valleys with the potential for some light showers. High temperatures will reach the low 30s on the peaks and mid 40s in the valleys. Ridgeline winds will be south westerly in the 10-20 mph range.
btac_bottomline: Human triggered avalanches remain possible today, especially in steep, rocky, wind exposed areas at the middle and upper elevations. Buried crust-facet combinations lurk on NE through E through S slopes, though their strength should continue improve after today's warm up and refreeze. Moniter the effects of the sun on the snow surface today and minimize exposure time on steep sunlit slopes.
legecast: 6 AM- Greetings and good morning on the final weekend of our 2022-23 ski season. It has been an amazing year, but we aren't done yet. So, hop out of bed, grab your snow sliding gear and jet. A mix of clouds and sunshine will dance across the sky today, alongside mild spring temperatures that rise to just above freezing at the summit and into the low 40's in Teton Village. Light to moderate winds from the West will play a supporting role as they blow between 10-20 mph. Stick around all day and celebrate with the sublime sounds of 40 oz. to Freedom, as they hit the stage beneath the tram at 3pm. Sometimes it seems our society only serves us distressing headlines and impending deadlines. Take refuge from the toxic madness by immersing yourself in purposeless good times. Because richness of the soul comes from skiing lines not chasing bottom lines. -Lege
gt_detail: Temperatures are beginning to warm up as we start the weekend. Expect patchy clouds today with moments of sunshine. There are still patches of good snow throughout the mountain if you know where to look. Happy Saturday!
Sierra_weatherdisc: A weather system moving through the forecast area today is expected to bring a period of steady snowfall this morning followed by snow showers this afternoon lasting into the evening hours. The greatest new snowfall amounts are expected directly along the Sierra Crest. New snow accumulation is expected to decrease dramatically east of the Sierra Crest. A warming trend is forecast to begin tomorrow with maximum daytime air temperatures for Sunday and Monday reaching the warmest since late October.
Sierra_btmline: Strong winds drifting new snowfall will create potentially unstable slabs of snow near ridgetops and in gully features. Areas of unstable wet snow may form in areas that receive rain on snow or afternoon sun. Move cautiously around avalanche terrain where wind drifted snow is depositing or where signs of surface wet snow exist.
Sierra_hazard_disc: Massive cornices exist along many ridgelines. Some have deep cracks behind them. A substantial warming event leading to some large cornice collapses is expected to occur during the Saturday to Monday timeframe.
UT_btmline: There is a CONSIDERABLE avalanche danger for wet avalanches on sunny slopes facing southeast through west. There is a MODERATE danger on slopes facing northwest through north and east, especially on any wind-loaded slopes. Cornices also present an avalanche hazard: stay well-back from corniced-ridgelines and avoid traveling on slopes with large, overhanging cornices above. With so much snow, watch out for roof avalanches especially as the day heats up.
UT_avyconditions: This Morning: Skies are clear and temperatures are in the mid 20's F. Winds are from the south/southwest and have increased overnight, gusting into the 20's mph at mid elevations and 40's at upper elevations. Today: Skies will cloud up this afternoon and temperatures will rise into the 30's and low 40's F, possibly creating some greenhousing at low and mid-elevations. The southwest winds will increase throughout the day, gusting into the 20's mph at mid elevations and into the 40's and 50's mph at upper elevations.  Looking Ahead: Warm and partly cloudy over the weekend, with very warm temperatures into early next week with temperatures remaining above freezing overnight.You should be able to find soft/dry snow on northerly aspects above about 9,000'. All other snow surfaces will be crusted from strong sunshine over the past two days.
UT_recentactivity: There was widespread natural and control work avalanche activity in Little Cottonwood Canyon on Thursday. These avalanches were 4-8' deep and several hundred feet wide, with some avalanches reaching the road. A few highlights include Grizzly Gulch, Mount Superior, and White Pine Chutes. Other notable avalanches that occurred during the storm on Tuesday or Wednesday morning include Cardiac Ridge and George's Bowl. It's worth looking through all recent avalanches from this recent storm cycle. The photo below is from the Grizzly Gulch avalanche - it was remotely triggered from an explosive 2,000' away and was 8' deep, 800' wide, and filled up the bottom of Grizzly Gulch with debris stopping 150' short of the Grizzly Gulch trailhead.
solitude_detail: It’s time, folks. Time for slushy thrills and soggy glory. Time to watch 100+ brave and flamboyant souls attempt to ski and ride across an 80-foot-long, three-foot-deep span of ice-cold water. It’s our Pond Skim Beach Party, and it’s not to be missed! The action starts at 1:00 p.m. on the slope outside of Last Chance Lodge. Enjoy food, live music — and spectacular crashes into the pond. Elsewhere on the mountain, most of our terrain is now open with spring conditions present. That means firm conditions to start the day with the snow getting softer by the hour. Temperatures should hang around the mid-30s for most of the day today. We’re expecting cloudy skies in the morning, but the sun should make an appearance by the time the first skimmer goes full send.
